title: Gunpowder Cellar of Tartu
text:
The Gunpowder Cellar () is a historic building in <a href="Tartu">Tartu</a>, <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a> which now functions as a <a href="beer">beer</a> <a href="restaurant">restaurant</a>.
The name is derived from the restaurant's location: it is situated in an 18th-century gunpowder cellar constructed in 1768–1778 by order of <a href="Catherine%20II%20of%20Russia">Catherine II of Russia</a> on the site of an earlier <a href="fort">fort</a>, making use of the natural valley and pre-existing very thick brick walls for added safety. The building served as a gunpowder cellar until 1809 when it was converted to a beer storage room. At the end of the 19th century the building began to be used by the <a href="University%20of%20Tartu">University of Tartu</a> which meant that lectures and scientific work were often conducted on top of gunpowder barrels. In the 1990s it functioned as a large medieval restaurant before reopening in 2001 as a pub and disco though retaining a wine cellar.
Its unique structure also lends it a unique distinction: it is in the "<a href="Guinness%20Book%20of%20World%20Records">Guinness Book of World Records</a>" for having the highest pub ceiling in the world, at .
The restaurant is a popular meeting place among Tartu's student population. It boasts a regular cultural programme, including a number of plays by the <a href="Vanemuine">Vanemuine</a> theatre. This programme includes regular live music events.
